title: Professional play is important, but can it stop being the sole reason for nerfs to a champ?
body: Literally have never seen anyone complain about Rek'Sai or claim she is OP outside of her release.

Stupid really.

You're misrepresenting yourself here.

Balancing only for professional play (with a few exceptions) would be balancing just for balance. 

For example, lets say Yi is balanced for pro play but dominates lower elo games. If I only care about objective balance, why would I nerf him? The players that're losing to him are losing because they're making mistakes, not playing well enough. Not because Yi is overpowered.

Whereas if the opposite is true, and he dominates pro play but is useless at any other level, then I have to nerf him for the sake of balance. Because when played optimally he's much too strong, and the players who aren't succeeding with him are failing because they aren't good enough, not because the champ isn't op.

Does that make sense? 


Also, I think your whole premise is pretty meh. If pro play exists, of course Riot will want to balance around it. Not only for buisiness concerns (the experience of pro players and the people watching them), but because advantages in pro play tend to slowly trickle down into being used by everyone else as players get better over time. (there are exceptions, of course.)

Sadly, I have to agree with you. Professional/High elo players are the only people who can bring out the full potential of champions. They show you exactly what a champion is capable of doing when played at their skill ceiling. 

Balancing around the "average" player would be a bad move because most of those people can't play champions to their full capability; so, these players don't actually know how strong/weak a champion can actually be. And your Master Yi example defines this perfectly. Master Yi is probably the most known "noob stomper." He completely dominates in low elo, but falls off heavily at the higher elos. 

If they want to balance champions, professional/high elo players are the best to look at if they want **true** balance.

I 100% agree with this, but it really sucks that a vast majority of the people who play this game are in that "low elo" that get fucked over by competitive players who are just so good at maximizing a champion's potential. I have friends that enjoyed playing those "OP" champs in competitive, only to see them now unusable (cough cough {{champion:429}} ). The sad truth is that (like you guys said) Riot **needs** to balance around LCS and really high elo players.
